remixed_from.author: PharaohABQ
remixed_from.title: Eric's Wade's Collaborative Dual Feed Extruder

title: dual grip upgrades for wades reloaded

description.text:
basically you add this to a wades reloaded, you need a second hobbed bolt of the same diameter, and two regular 608 bearings and one preferably grooved 608.  
I haven't made the gears yet that transfer power to the second bolt yet though.

comments.text: Looks interesting. When making the gears, remember that the hobbed bolts will be turning opposite directions, unless we use a belt rather than gears. Adding this to a standard unmodded wades may be tough.  It's looking like you may be planning a second idler.  On my gears, I had them offset so closed they'd mesh, closed tighter they'd still mesh, but the offset allowed more wiggle room.
comments.author: PharaohABQ

comments.text: to clarify all I did was essentially modify your idler by adding the hinge, and removing the idler you added to the top of the wades  reloaded frame. also I did add some length to the piece in order to fit the bolt holes.
comments.author: PharaohABQ

comments.text:
That looks pretty awesome, Bulky, but not as much as mine. We loose a little print height with it being so tall as well. In a Bowden setup this would be great. I do really love that you've not had to mod the original Wades.
As for the gears. Gears mesh actually in the center of the teeth, so you just draw two circles that intersect at half the depth of your gear teeth. That's how you then are able to make the gears the right size.
By offset, I meant that the idler gear closes on the radius of the idler itself, so as the idler closes, the Idler Gear moves over the top of the extruder gear, engaging before it's fully closed, and would be fully engaged when it is fully closed, then the width of the filament in the extruder pushes it out maybe 1 degree, which isn't a big deal since it would just loosen the teeth maybe .05mm on a 1mm change, accounting for the teeth of the hobbed bolt. 3mm wouldn't be much different at all. You can model this, pretty easily. Herringbone teeth would pull all the slop out of the gears even if you had 5mm filament.
As for closing this, Currently you have 4 screws and springs needed, I'd been thinking of some kind of a latch like on a toolbox but with springs to hold this shut. Best I've come up with is putting a spring on a 40mm bolt, with washers on each end, then putting it through the idler compressing the spring and latching into the Wades to pull the idler toward the extruder, It's kind of backward from the standard, but for me it works better. See my Blown Wades Extruder for the example of that. Basically slotting the Wades, rather than the Guidler.
comments.author: DFarms

comments.text: there I printed it last night, it came out pretty nicely, and fits perfectly. for me the extra height is not an issue because i have a corexy machine, and i might convert it to bowden now that this is coming along nicely.
comments.author: PharaohABQ

comments.text: Great! That looks awesome.  I wonder how well it will push filament through a smaller head?  It should work with the Blown Wades too.  I think people are going to love that. The idlers are a little tall, so in Rev2 you can dump the stock idler and shorten it with your own, but that may be down the road a bit.  Nice job though!
comments.author: DFarms

comments.text: yeah the only issue is that because i couldnt get the correct gear size still, its a little large, it torques the top sideways. I think if i can make the teeth thinner and the overall size of the gear about 10% smaller it will be perfect.
comments.author: PharaohABQ

comments.text: Yeah, the top and bottom gears need to be the same size or one feed will be pulling the next....   I've been thinking of another design for this:  One Idler bearing pressing on two hobbed bolts driven by 1 stepper off a large gear.  The two hobbed bolts will push the filament around the bearing on two contact points. This should accomplish basically the same concept as we've been doing, but be much more compact. might like to make it with Dremel bits too, to see how those work out.
comments.author: DFarms

comments.text: the ideal thing to grab the filament with would be maybe a 2inch or so hobbed gear, you would have a piece of delrin or something slick that would push the filament into the teeth around a quarter turn of the hobbed gear. you might be able to arrange some small bearings instead of the delrin but that would be quite tricky.
comments.author: PharaohABQ

author: AbuShaqra92

description.text:
Hello!
This is just a simple air turbine.
Needed parts are:
3x 4mm screws
1x M8 threaded rod or axle
2x pipe fittings
2x skateboard bearings
M8 tap(i think it's called that) to make the threads.
superglue to fasten the rod or axle.
simply hook up to air compressor or vacuum and it rotates.

comments.text:
yes, if you apply air pressure, it will turn around.
But what's the theory of function? Your caves have the same volumina every time. A pump or turbine has variable volume of the chambers. Your pump has the same volume around. Air will come in a chamber and will give the same force forward and back. In theory your pump will not rotate, in practical life it will - with extremely bad efficiency.
Do not use this for education model.
comments.author: faggahz

comments.text: Thank you for your input i appreciate constructive criticism and yes it does not have very good efficiency. It's more of a fun creation/gadget. But please note that i do not claim to be an engineer. I will probably continue this design in the future with your comment in consideration.
comments.author: faggahz

title: Alunar XY Axis Alignment braces
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: The Alunar is a great budget printer but the XY axis were not orthogonal and need to be squared up to produce more accurate parts. These parts mount on the front base plate threaded rods (inboard side of the base) and on the z axis guide rods at the bottom. Use a piece of 5/16-18 all-thread rod cut to 9.5 inches length and then use them to push or pull the X and Y axis into alignment. You will have to loosen the center nuts on the base threaded rods to allow the y axis to move and them re-tighten after it is aligned. To square the bed out I suggest using a 6 inch machinist square short side on the X axis guide rods and slide the y axis back and forth checking for a parallel clearance to the bed edge through out the travel. If you bed is crooked align it to the y axis first and then repeat the above process and adjust the nuts on the new threaded rods equally on both sides (one pushing and one pulling) until it is square. I was able to achieve a nearly perfect square by visual inspection of the clearance gap and after printing a squaring gauge it was perfectly square over 150mm run in both x and y directions.

Printer:

Alunar

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

25-40%

Notes:

Parts are not dimensionally critical but hole sizes should be 8mm for the Z axis guide rod mounts; i.e. do not scale it is the proper size already.

Duplicate and then Mirror the left block to produce the right block, see the .txt files for more instructions

title: Rolling Cylinder - DIY Moment of Inertia Experiment

description.text:
This project allows you to have a educational introduction to the Moment of Inertia. The presented rolling cylinder has two chambers with equal volume. Having two cylinders: one filled the inner, the other filled the outer chamber, gives you two optically equal objects with totally different Moment of Inertia.

If the mass fo the rigid body is close to the rotation axis, the Moment of Inertia is rather small. Mass distributed distant to the rotations axis will lead to a rather big Moment of Inertia.

Let the cylinders roll down a inclined surface to present the unequal physical charactersitics. Since the Moment of Inertia determines the needed torque for a desired angular acceleration, the cylinder with the inner chamber filled will accelerate faster and reach the end of the inclined surface first.

Check my video showing a summary of the project:
https://youtu.be/ZB_kgVMti_E

Consinder the Rolling Racers animation, where all bodies do have the same mass:

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

There is no need for support rafts for printing the cylinder.

Printing the cap of the cylinder might require rafts. I printed the cap laying down flat with rafts in the closing circle slit and in the handle on top of the cap. In order to have a nice fitting of the cap and the cylinder, make sure to completly remove the rafts of the closing slit in the cap. Rasping and sanding leads to better fitting as well.

Make sure to print the cylinder and cap two times. So you can have a comparison of the two different Moments of Interia and therefore a race competition between to cylinders. This will make your experiment even more fun - for more information see project details below.

Since I'm teaching physics in highschool I know what it means to kids to experience physics in an experiment. Teaching stuff from books is fundamental and important. But the perfomance of experiments leads to better understanding and memories!

Because of the high costs of educational material, alot of school are not able to perform science experiments. Therefore I decided to design some things, which are easily printed and therefore low-cost-experiments.

Back in my schooldays I was fascinated of the experiment about the Moment of Inertia. Since there was no optical nor a weight difference in the bodys rolling down the inclined surface it looked like magic to me.

Thanks to this great memory I started designing this thing to provide a comprehensible experiment which allows everbody to understand the physical concept of Moment of Inertia.

I designed this by constraining the two volumes of the two chambers to be equal. Therefore filling the chambers up will lead to an equal weight!

description.header: Project: Rolling Cylinder - DIY Moment of Inertia Experiment
description.text:
Overview & Background:

By completing this project you will be able to have a hands-on experience and easy understanding about the Moment of Inertia. This project provides multiple options of usage:

The cylinder might act as:

  • a hands-on DIY project for students
  • a phenomenological introduction to the moment of inertia
  • a qualitative lesson about the moment of inertia, including math
Objectives:

Students will experience the impact of the moment of inertia. By completing the project they will have a hands-on project to learn about the kinematics of rigid bodies.

Additionally this projects provides the opportunity to make some mathematical calculations about the moment of inertia.

Audiences:

Students at the age of 10-16 in physics or science.

Subjects:

This project is a physics / science project for high school classes.

Skills Learned (Standards):

Students building and interact with this project are going to learn:

  • the basics of mechanics
  • the physics of rotating rigid bodies
  • the physics of mass distribution
Lesson/Activity:

How to build the Rolling Cylinder

You’ll need the following things:

  • the 3d printed parts: cylinder + cap (2 times)
  • some candles
  • a (kitchen) scale

Follow the video (gallery) in order to build the Rolling Cylinder.

First you have to print the 3d parts. Make sure to print the cylinder + cap two times. After printing, safely remove the support rafts and use some sandpaper in order to have a nice fitting.

Once your 3d parts are printed you have to get some (old) candles. About 250g grams should be enough. Put them in a pot. Take another pot with boiling water to melt the candle wax. Don’t worry about the 3d printing material to melt. Since I did some tests and it always survived without having any scratch.

Once the wax is liquid, you have to safely fill it into the cylinders. Start with the inner-chamber-filled-cylinder first, since this one is easier. Make sure to not fill any wax into the outer chamber by protecting it with plastic wrap or something else.

Fill up the inner chamber till about 1cm under the edge of the inner chamber (see pictures). Now use a scale to figure out the mass of it. Place the second cylinder aka outer-chamber-filled-cylinder on the scale and start filling up the outer chamber. Stop filling it up as soon as you reach the same mass like the first cylinder.

The wax will take about 15 minutes to cool down. When cooling, down the volume of the wax will decrease. Therefore it will sink down a bit. But don’t worry, since the weight will be the same this is no problem for the later physical characteristics of the cylinder.

Now you should have to cylinders looking almost the same, having the same weight, but still, have different physical characteristics.

Let’s see about the physics in the next section:

Physics:

In order to provide a good experiment, we need to take some heavy (high density) material. Therefore the physical aspects will appear even clearer. I think the easiest way is taking candle wax, but I did also think of gypsum or some kind of cement. These materials might all work well, you just have to be very cautious about the equal weight of the two cylinders.
Using 3d printed PLA, ABS or whatever will probably have too low density and therefore you might not be able to see any difference in the matter of moment of inertia.

Okay, just in case you are still wondering and did not yet google it:

What is the moment of inertia?

"The moment of inertia, otherwise known as the angular mass or rotational inertia, of a rigid body determines the torque needed for a desired angular acceleration about a rotational axis. It depends on the body's mass distribution and the axis chosen, with larger moments requiring more torque to change the body's rotation." (Wikipedia)

Starting with the kinetic energy of a rotating rigid body, which is the sum of all mass points mi:

Applying the angular velocity:

Because all mass points are rotating around one axis with a given distance ri. So we get:

The bracketed part at the end of the equation is called moment of inertia:

For bodies with continuous mass distribution we have to integrate (instead of summation) over all mass points:

Knowing this will give us the opportunity to calculate the moment of inertia of several different bodies. Let’s start with an easy one:

Calculate the moment of inertia of a ring

Assuming a ring with the mass mr and the radius rr. The rotation axis is perpendicular to the surface of the ring and through the middle point of the ring. The entire mass is concentrated in the distance rr. Therefore we get a moment of inertia of:

Calculate the moment of inertia of a disk

The next step is calculating the moment of inertia of a flat disk with radius rd and the mass md. Again the rotation axis is perpendicular to the surface of the disk and through the middle point of the disk. It should appear clear that the moment of inertia of this disk is smaller than the one of the ring, since the mass is distributed from r=0 and r=rd. Therefore more mass is closer to the rotation axis than it is for the ring. Imaging the disk as a summation of multiple mass-element-rings. The area of one mass element is:

Since the mass is distributed homogeneous we find the area density to be:

With this we find one mass element to be:

Putting all this together, we are able to calculate the moment of inertia of the disk:

As expected the moment of inertia of the disk is smaller than the one of the ring.

Calculate the moment of inertia of a cylinder

In order to apply the calculation to our purpose we have to figure out the moment of inertia of a cylinder. Therefore we assume a cylinder with the mass mc and the radius rc. Imaging the cylinder as a summation of multiple disks with the masses dm and the moment of inertia of (as calculated above):

Integrating over all disks will give us the moment of inertia of the cylinder, which is:

Now we should be able to calculate the moment of inertia of the cylinders we are using. But bevor doing so I would like to introduce another way of calculating the moment of inertia of a cylinder, which is by using the cylindrical coordinates:

Using cylindrical coordinates

Depending of the math skills of your students you might be able to introduce the cylindrical coordinates to them. Therefore the moment of inertia is a very good example.

Forget about the ring and the disk, since we now want to start from scratch. By using cylindrical coordinates, it is helpful to integrate of the volume of the cylinder with multiple integrals. As you might know the volume of a cylinder is:

The density is defined as:

Together we get an equation for the mass of the cylinder:

Ok, let’s try to figure out the moment of intertia:

Since the mass distribution is assumed homogeneous we might omit the dependency of the density to r. We’ll now integrate three times: First the height of the cylinder, then the angle of the bottom area, last the radius of the bottom circle:

Don’t you think this was much easier? I think so, too!

Conclusion

Ok, since I want to leave some room for other educators I will stop doing math now. Just to give you some ideas of what else you could do with this project in your class, consider the following list:

  • calculate the explicit moment of inertia for the two cylinders
  • calculate the estimated times the cylinders take to roll down any inclined surface (tip: using potential and kinetic energy)
  • let the students try to figure out the biggest and the lowest moment of inertia of a fictive body

As you can see there are a lot of applications to this project. Maybe you’ll have some other interesting ideas of interacting with this project. I would appreciate if you could share it, in order to improve the project and have a more awesome experiment students can interact and learn with.

Duration:

Strongly depends on chosen content for teaching:

  1. Just presenting the rolling cylinders as a phenomenological experiment: about 0.5h

  2. Presenting the rolling cylinders, discuss about the physics and have some calculations about the moment of inertia: about 2h

  3. Presenting the rolling cylinders, discuss about the physics and have a lot of calculations including the moment of inertia calculation with cylindrical coordinates and the theoretical estimation of the needed time the cylinders will take to roll down an inclined surface: about 4h
Preparation:

Students should know about:

  • physics of kinematics of rigid bodies
  • integral calculations
References:
  • most likely every high school physics book will have a section including the moment of inertia
  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moment_of_inertia
  • http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/mi.html
Rubric & Assessment:

At the end of the project, students should have:

  • (optional: printed and successfully built the rolling cylinders)
  • observed and understood the physical aspects of the moment of inertia
  • made some calculations about the moment of inertia and therefore
  • learned the math about the moment of inertia
  • (optional: learned cylindrical coordinates)

Grading and assessment of the students:

  • the overall behavior in this project
  • did they manage to figure out the moment of inertia of the two cylinders?
  • did they manage to calculate the moment of inertia using cylindrical coordinates?
  • did they manage to calculate the estimated time the cylinders take to roll down the inclined surface?
  • How do we have to imagine the mass distribution of a body with the smallest (/biggest) moment of inertia?
Have Fun!

title: Mini Optical Sensor Cover (for Da Vinci Jr)

description.text:
I had to repair an optical sensor on my Da Vinci Jr by replacing the IR emitter and detector (the LED was blown). I purchased your standard garden variety optical endstops from Amazon, but the connector was oriented a different way, the components were too close together and it was generally not compatible with the endstop on the Jr.

So I simply desoldered and removed the components and swapped them out, but the components have a larger form factor than the stock Da Vinci Jr endstop. The stock clip that both shields the components and clips the endstop into the chassis did not have a large enough clearance for the new parts, and it also is open on the front and back, leaving the emitter and detector unshielded.

This part is meant to replace the stock clip, while fitting the larger components that I soldered into the original board. I'm still tweaking some things to get it to clip in correctly. Most recently I extended the clip legs by 0.5mm.

Printer:

XYZPrinting Da Vinci Jr

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

None

Notes:

This part has extremely thin walls and small parts -- only a single extrusion width all the way around. You must be very careful in your slicing and printing to ensure that all surfaces are printed.

The model has three parts for ease of printing -- two "towers" to shield the components, then the clip that holds the board in place.

Layer height matters because of the triangular clip pieces. Use 0.1 layer height to ensure these are true to form.

Print in black. I used PLA but the material shouldn't matter.

After printing you can glue the towers to the clip before installation if desired, or leave them loose (which may be necessary if your components are a little too tall). If you leave them loose, just make sure the towers are oriented straight at each other for correct operation.

Designed in Tinkercad after carefully measuring the original piece with calipers. The original clip has two "ears" that extend toward the JST connector and clip it in place, but I've left these out for simplicity. The clip works fine without them.

description.text: The Owl Pellet Discovery Kit is a realistic, durable, reusable and multi-use owl pellet model for student dissection. It acts as a base for a larger project where students design additional bones and pieces. The 3-D models in this kit include a mouse skull, rib bone and a femur. Typical owl pellets can also contain beaks, talons and many different bones that are held together by undigested fur which is simulated by a dryer-lint formula in this project.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No
Rodent Skull, Femur, Rib

Designed Tips

Based on dissection of an owl pellet with real bones, I designed these models using 123D Design and 123D Catch. I recommend putting a base under any bones that are lopsided or unbalanced. If you have some portion that overhangs, add a support which you can later snip off after printing. Flipping a bone upside down for printing can also eliminate overhangs. If you use 123D Catch you need to take a sufficient number of photographs to create your model - Catch will prompt you if more photos are required to generate the mesh. 123D Design's capabilities allow you to add intricate parts to your design and manipulate them, but you can also work with basic shapes.

For the skull model included here, after completion of the design I inverted the piece to ensure printing would have a steady base. A raft was added for printing of the very thin, small rib bone and femur - the rafts easily snapped off after printing but gave a solid foundation during printing and until cool.

Project Name

Owl Pellet Discovery Kit

Overview & Background

Students will learn to dissect owl pellets and identify bones; advanced students or higher grade levels will also design a new replica piece, modeled upon a picture of a small rodent bone or bird skeleton, for inclusion in the dissection pellet.

Dissection of a real Owl Pellet takes extreme care to reveal many fragile bones and non-digestible peices Objectives

Students in 4th-8th grade will be expected to 3-D print the bones included here as well as creating one new bone/piece of their own (this can be done individually or in small groups). Students can use a photo of a bone to design a replica. They are expected to print their newly designed bone for inclusion in the pellet, thus the collection of bones available for future pellet dissections continues to increase and becomes varied. Students will then create an owl pellet (recipe provided) including the 3-D printed items and then through dissection identify the pieces they discover. If students are given random assortments of 3-D printed items each group or individual will have a unique set of pellet contents.

Students in 2nd-4th grade can also complete this project with focus being on the dissection and identification process; teachers can prepare pellets ahead of time for this lesson.

Audiences

Grades 4-8 are able to complete this entire project. For younger audiences it can be simplified and design of a new piece may be excluded or completed as a class. In more advanced Design, Biology or Anatomy classes the quantity or skill level of bone selection for design can be increased.

Subjects
  • Science
  • Animal Studies
  • Biology
  • Design/CAD
Skills Learned (Standards)
  • Dissection/Fine Motor Coordination
  • Identifying/Scientific Reasoning
  • Following Instructions
  • Deductive Reasoning/Making an Educated Guess
  • 3-D Design - 123D Design, TinkerCAD or similar
  • Creative Thinking
  • Using a 3-D printer
Lesson/Activity

Materials:
Dissection probe, tweezers, magnifying glass, 3-D printer, CAD software, replica pellet bones, replica pellet ingredients (see References), skeleton charts or pictures for reference (see pdf Thing file).

Step-by-Step Overview:

  1. 3-D Print the 3 bone models provided in this project. Each student pellet or pellet dissection group should have a full set of these 3 models.
  2. Creation of a new or unique bone or non-digestible part of the student's choosing (grades 4-8) This can be done individually or in small groups depending on design skill level of students and accessibility of computers.
  3. 3-D Print student's newly designed bones, talons or beaks.
  4. Prepare Owl Pellet "recipe" (found under References).
  5. Assemble replica Owl Pellets using printed pieces and pellet recipe. Teacher could hand out random sets of 3-D printed bones (approx 4 per pellet) for each pellet or students could assemble pellets with the 3 provided here plus their own new creation.
  6. Allow for drying time of at least 48 hours, possibly 60-72 for pellets to be ready for dissection.
  7. Dissection of Pellet including Identification of contents. It is suggested that students be given pellets randomly so they do not know what bones they will discover and can then identify them from the charts provided.
Examples of actual owl pellet bone and non-digestible parts for additional design insipration Duration

This project could take 5 hours of classroom time and should be incorporated and interwoven with lecture and discussion within the Animal Studies or Biology curriculum :

  • 1 hour Printing (for 3 bone models provided here)
  • 2 hours Design (new pellet creations)
  • 20-25 minutes to print new creation (per item)
  • 30-45 minutes (preparation of multiple pellets)
  • up to 1 hour Dissection

There is also a drying time for pellet mixture of 48-60 hours - leaving pellets to dry over a weekend would be ideal. Printing time need not be classroom time - the printer could be running throughout the day or after-school hours.

Preparation

Students should be introduced to a unit on Animal Studies or Biology and the concept of food chains. They should also be familiar with AutoDesk 123D Design or TinkerCAD and the operation of their 3-D printer.

Collection of sufficient quantities of dryer lint should also be assigned prior to a class beginning this project.

Skeleton pictures should be available - there are several samples here, but in textbooks or online, teachers may find something most appropriate for their level or learners. Owl pellets can contain a variety of small rodent bones (mouse, vole, mole, chipmunk) as well as small bird parts or frog bones, even small lizards/salamanders. The kind of skeleton charts and number of different kinds of prey to be studied should be determined by the time frame allotted for Animal Studies and the grade level of participants.

References

Students (or teachers) will need to create the Owl Pellets 3-4 days prior to Dissection.

Owl Pellet Recipe

You will Need:

  • Dryer lint - at least 1 tennis ball sized handful per pellet
  • Water
  • White School Glue (liquid, not glue stick)
  • Small bowl
  • Cookie Tray or Drying Rack
  1. In small bowl dissolve 1 tsp. glue into 4 TBSP water (mixing with finger tips dissolves glue rapidly)
  2. Hand shred dryer lint into the bowl
  3. Drop replica bones/pieces into the mixture - it should be lumpy, consistency of stew. Additional water or glue can be added if lint quantity is larger or mixture is too dry.
  4. Gently take the pulp mixture out of the bowl, folding and scooping into your hand. Resting the pulp in the bend of your fingers, gently squeeze until no liquid runs out. It should be generally pellet shaped from being squeezed, you can squish the ends inward to make pellet shape wider if it is too long or thin.
  5. Allow 24-60 hours for pellet to dry.
Pellet Creation Process: clockwise from upper left - Lint Material, Bowl with pellet mixture, Wet Pellet, Fully Dried Ready-to-Dissect Replica Pellet Rubric & Assessment

Student designs can be completed individually or in small groups. Grading of 3-D design models could be based on ACCURACY of details, COMPLEXITY of bone/piece and preparation for SUCCESSFUL PRINTING or other criteria a teacher deems relevant to the lesson and level of design experience of students.

Student Dissection could be evaluated by correct IDENTIFICATION of bones/pieces (compare/contrast with skeleton graphics), DISCOVERY of all models located within the pellet (how thoroughly did student dissect pellet).

Assessment could also be made of student knowledge of concepts taught within the Animal Studies unit. An understanding of food chains or owl diet and digestion would be likely and the higher grade levels would have a great introduction to skeletal anatomy of small rodents and birds.

Handouts & Assets

There are a multitude of skeletal images available online for use in the identification process during dissection of a pellet and for inspiration when choosing what item to design and 3-D print. The following samples are to show the range of simple to complex skeletons which can be used for varying grade levels, all were found by simple image search online. Teachers may use these or something similar to supplement any textbook diagrams or other handouts they have as part of their Animal Studies or other Science unit.

Included here are a few samples (see photos below and the attached pdf document).

Simple mouse skeleton with main bones identified. Complex small rodent (vole) skeleton with more detailed labeling of bone structure. Small bird skeleton, thoroughly labeled. Alternate bird skeleton including body structure for visual understanding of bone location. Alternate small rodent skeleton scientifically displayed.

Tuiles utilisant les dimensions des tuiles True Tiles par Wyloch's Armory et les murs OpenForge Tudor.

Ces tuiles sont donc compatible avec celles du système True Tiles .

Dimension True Tiles

Chaque case des tuiles fait 31.25 mm de côté et les murs 6.25 mm de large pour une hauteur de 18.75mm. Ainsi les murs peuvent être incorporés à une case tout en laissant 25mm, soit la taille du socle d'une figurine de taille M.

Pourquoi pas 25mm comme tout le monde ?
Et bien parce que cela laisse la place pour poser un mur de 6.25 mm sur le bord de la case et laisse justement encore 25mm pour la figurine.

Mais c'est quoi ces mesures tordus et pas 5mm ?
Parce que Wyloch il mesure avec ses pieds, euh pouces, et fait ses tuiles en ce sens, donc pour les murs 1/4 de pouces soit 6.25mm. Oui c'est chiant, mais ainsi on reste compatible avec la communauté qui produit en ce sens.

Supports pour Magnetball 5mm

Des supports pour Magnetball 5mm à la taille des tuiles ont étés aussi ajoutés. Très pratique, vous ajoutez donc ses aimants en forme de bille dans les trous des supports et collez la tuile dessus. Ainsi les tuiles s'attachent et s'ajustent automatiquement les unes aux autres.

English Comment

Tiles using the tiles dimensions of True Tiles by Wyloch's Armory and OpenForge walls Tudor design.

These tiles are compatible with those of True Tiles.

Each square tiles is 1.25 '' of side and walls 0.25 '' wide for a height of 0.75 ''. So the walls can be incorporated into a square while leaving 1 '', the size of a miniature base size M.

Supports for Magnetball 5mm size tiles have also be added. Very practical, so you add this ball-shaped magnets in the bracket holes and paste the tile above. Thus the tiles are attached and adjusted automatically to each other.

title: Ultimate Slug Trap With Tongs (beer time !)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I don't grow greens to feed the slugs which are any gardener's nightmare !

Rain and wind can be strong here and I wanted a trap with good protection of the beer reservoir. I wanted it to be secured into the ground to stand any weather. It would be great if that trap can be printed easily in one single step. I added a pair of tongs to don't waste beer or have any unpleasant little drinkers removal.

It's slug's happy hour, enjoy !

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
28/08/2016: Updated file for better fit against the core

If you're into building and talking about esk8s then come pay us a visit: http://www.electric-skateboard.builders/

The pre-bored holes are intended for 10-24 tap. If you dont have access to a tap, you can drill these out a little larger using a number 25 drill bit for imperial (.150") which is 3.81mm in metric so 4mm would also work. Once you secure a good fit on your wheels, a bead of superglue on the threads of the screw is encouraged to prevent the screws from coming loose due to vibrations. Loctite is great for metal on metal but not metal on plastic. So super glue is the best for this application.

10-24 by 2 Inch Machine Screws work perfectly with this design and will not hit your trucks (Caliber or Paris) and probably other though I have not tested others myself.

No modifications to your trucks are required for use.

Enjoy.

There is tons of work that went into making these and the other pulley series on here so if you wish to contribute feel free to donate any amount you wish.

title: GoPro Gyro
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My son recently bought a GoPro Hero4 Session camera. I designed the "gyro" for my work and customized it by adding a fixture/handle, making it fit the standard GoPro Hero line of accessories. You can find a camera mount here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53680 and add a handle such as: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:278035 or http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:487964. You only need 4 M5 nuts for the middle ring. The six holes in the outer ring is only there to strengthen the geometry. You may wish to use M5 nuts in some of them if you are planning to use the gimball with a more expensive (or heavier) camera than the GoPro. Thankyou to the community for sharing your designs. Please share photos if you make your own. You only need the following 5 STL-files: Ring1_Core + Ring2_Flat + Ring2_HexSide + Ring3 + 4xDybler_8.6_14.2mm.
PS: For the bold: Gyro_M5_Assembled.stl is printable in one go and completes in 3 hours and 40 minutes with 60 mm/sek and 0.15 mm layerthickness. You need to spend some time cleaning away supportmaterial and "massage" the axis to get rid of the friction. Please note, that I have updated the orientation of the handle in relation to the axis since the first print.

author: Nleinad

title: Ukulele Humidifier
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Nothing is worse than finding a crack in your Ukulele because the wood has dried out. Prevent this tragedy by making a Humidifier for your instruments!

Slips between the center two strings and snaps into place. keep your instrument humidified while in it's case. Designed not to drip!

This may possibly work on acoustic guitars as well.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard (.2mm layer height)

Infill:

10% infill

Additional materials:

Wet type Floral foam
1 Tyvek priority mail envelope
a pair of scissors
a sharp knife or a razor blade

Assembly:

Print all 3 parts.
cut two pieces of Tyvek from the envelope: one to fit in the inside of the lid, the other to fit down the interior of the box along the side with the two circular holes. this is to create a moisture barrier that allows water vapor to escape the box, but keeps water from dripping.

Using the knife or razor blade, cut a piece of floral foam to fit the interior of the box. insert foam into the box, being sure the tyvek is sandwiched between the holes on the side of the box and the foam.
using scissors, trim one column and one row of squares from the Dryseal screen part, so it fits on top of the foam, centered between the walls of the box. the cap and tyvek should snap over this on top of the box. Both the lid and this screen should be removed prior to filling the unit.

FIlling and use:

Remove the lid and the screen from the top of the unit. Place the unit in a coffee cup, and pour in distilled water, and let the box sit for a minute or two. Remove the box, replace the screen and snap the cap on the box. shake off any loose moisture on the outside of the unit and pat dry with a towel.

Insert the box, cap first, in between the center two strings and into the sound hole, with the two circular holes on the side of the box facing towards the headstock. push it in past the two detents near the bottom, locking it in place. If you are confused, please watch the accompanying video here: https://youtu.be/asUZs18bSWQ

The instrument should be fine for 5 days to a week. Check the foam every 4 days or so to make sure it's still damp, and rehydrate the foam when it's dry. For best results, keep the instrument in it's bag or case.

title: Kiev 10/15 Lens To Leica M Body (Techart Pro LM-EA7) Adapter

description.text:
The Kiev 10 was the first Soviet-built 35mm SLR with automatic exposure. It did this using an internal linkage for the body to control the lens aperture -- there is no aperture control ring on the lens. The same lens mount was used by the Kiev 15 TEE, but nothing else, and the internal aperture linkage makes adapting to another mount problematic.

Thing 1464062 is an adapter I designed to mount these lenses directly on Sony E bodies, allowing a slight turn of the lens to adjust the aperture. This adapter is very similar (on the Kiev 10/15 end), but adapts to Leica M body mount. Why? To use these manual lenses with autofocus on the latest Sony E bodies via the Techart Pro LM-EA7 adapter!

The last two shots were taken using the LM-EA7 autofocus on an A7II with a Jupiter 9.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

A very straightforward print. I used "dishwasher safe" high-temp black PLA. It should be a little tight, so work a lens in the mount a bit before attaching to a camera -- that way, you can clean any little shards that the flange might cut the first time you fit a lens to it.

Usage Note:

For those who have looked at Kiev 10/15 lenses, the obvious issue is that they don't have aperture rings... so how do you adjust the aperture given that this adapter has no moving parts?

It's very simple: you turn the lens slightly. The lens mounts with a fairly extreme rotation, but doesn't lock. Once you've rotated it into place, there is a little nub on the inside that will catch the internal aperture control lever on the back of the lens mount. Then turning it slightly opens/closes the aperture... no markings, but still very usable.

Features:

-Rotating back-end
-Bit friction clipholder inside

This is a screwdriver handle for medium long bits. For people in Scandinavia : It is designed for these bits bought in Biltema:
http://www.biltema.se/sv/Verktyg/Handverktyg/Skruvmejslar-och-Bits/Bitssats/Specialbitssats-36-delar-2000018812/
These are 36 all round bits and for this amount of screw bits and with this handle you get a super cheap good set of screwdrivers.

I also gave a bit of silicone lube to ease the friction. now they really work well, and the bitholder holds the bits from dropping out nicely.
UPDATE2:
V4 is latest improved version, the bitsnap holder is better and the cap may work to just snap on there and stay, if not, there is already a hole for a screw M2.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
28/08/2016: Updated file for better fit against the core

If you're into building and talking about esk8s then come pay us a visit: http://www.electric-skateboard.builders/

The pre-bored holes are intended for 10-24 tap. If you dont have access to a tap, you can drill these out a little larger using a number 25 drill bit for imperial (.150") which is 3.81mm in metric so 4mm would also work. Once you secure a good fit on your wheels, a bead of superglue on the threads of the screw is encouraged to prevent the screws from coming loose due to vibrations. Loctite is great for metal on metal but not metal on plastic. So super glue is the best for this application.

10-24 by 2 Inch Machine Screws work perfectly with this design and will not hit your trucks (Caliber or Paris) and probably other though I have not tested others myself.

No modifications to your trucks are required for use.

Enjoy.

There is tons of work that went into making these and the other pulley series on here so if you wish to contribute feel free to donate any amount you wish.

description.text:
Wanted a simple clip for the back of my rack. This clip needs a M3x16mm flat head screw for mounting, but that's about it!

After a quick test where it immediately exploded, I tried a vapor bath to boost layer adhesion; no luck.

I think this might need to be broken up into two pieces so the stresses aren't perpendicular to the layers.
Dock for kitchen sponge

A scaled up and sectioned version of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:831868.

After being on a tall ship that had a "Hippie Horn" sitting by the ship's wheel, I thought it could be 3D-printable. I found dougfieg's "One Piece Deafening Horn" and scaled it up to match the one I saw on the ship. To get it to print on my early Printrbot Simple's limited Z-axis range, I split it up and added some joiner rings.

After assembly, I rubber-banded a balloon to the tympanic end. It produces a loud sound something like a vuvuzela, but with a lot less effort.

title: Vibration Damper for Prusa i3 mk2

description.text:
This is my take on lazzymonk's vibration dampers, dimensioned to fit under a Prusa i3.

There are two versions. One standard sized, and one "mini" version for those that have a small enclosure or otherwise not enough clearance for the standard sized ones.

When you've decided which version to use, you need two of the STL files for each damper, and then 4x of that setup.
For example, for the standard size you need to print 4x of Half_18.STL and 4x of Half_22.STL.

If the printer shakes, common sense tells you that it's bad. But that only means that the vibrational energy is absorbed by the dampers instead of the printer's frame and its connecting components, which should in theory improve the printer quality.

But if you feel like the shaking is too much, then you can add this line to your slicer's starting script:
"M204 S750"
where 750 is acceleration in mm/s^2. This can be changed to whatever you like. Lower number means a slower acceleration.

And for everyone else who still want to remark on these feet affecting your print quality: https://www.instagram.com/p/BM7oaqoAPpk/

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 Mk2

Notes:

Make sure youre slicer is set to 0,40mm extrusion width, otherwise you will lose out on a lot of strength and stability.

comments.text: These work great for reducing the noise of the Y axis steppers on my Prusa i3 MK2. For other i3 user I would very strongly recommend removing the included felt feet to insure the dampeners get a good grip on the printers 'legs'. In addition I added some electrical tape to the bottom of the print to make sure they don't slide around. Unfortunately the shear force of the Y motors and the sliding feet caused the printer to creep up to the edge of my desk and the front to feet slid off. Luckily the other half of the printer remained on the table but the spool was flung off and riped out the filament causing some minor nozzle clogging issues.

comments.text: These are not "dampers". Damping implies energy dissipation which these have minimal. All you're are doing is shifting the resonant frequency of the assembly by lowering the stiffness of the contact points, which may make some moves better and will just make other moves worse, in this case lower frequency moves since Resonant Frequency = (1/2pi)sqrt(stiffness/mass) . The best coarse of action is to anchor it to a rigid table and lower the acceleration limit.
comments.author: crcr

comments.text: You know, there is no need to get these if you think you have  a better solution.
comments.author: crcr

comments.text: Or even better design a "true" damper. The goal of these is to reduce noise, so if they do that by shifting the resonant frequency or preventing it from coupling into the base it's sitting on, great.

title: Robo3d Raspberry Pi Mount with Outlet

description.text:
I recently started playing around with Octoprint and I found out that I love it. I wanted to permanently mount a Raspberry Pi 3 to my printer to control it wirelessly, while powering everything from one power source. After many hours of figuring out the best location, I came up with a solution that works for me. I also decided that I would use Octoprint to turn the printer on and off, so I added two relay mounts (one for the power and another for LED's). I can still kill all the power with the main switch on the back of the Robo3d, since I don't always want it on. Anyways I hope you like it and it can work for you.

I made some changes to the mount after I printed mine, but the measurements are still the same. I also had to drill 4 holes into my Robo3D and I used laptop screws to secure it. Only the top two usb ports will be accessible.

Please note that you are working with A/C currents and must be extremely careful. If you do not know what you are doing then get someone that does. Always unplug the main power before attempting to make any changes.

Raspberry Pi
https://www.raspberrypi.org/

Octoprint
http://octoprint.org/

Controlling a relay board from your RPi
https://github.com/foosel/OctoPrint/wiki/Controlling-a-relay-board-from-your-RPi

5V Relay Module (similar to this one)
https://www.amazon.com/Tolako-Module-Arduino-Official-Boards/dp/B00VRUAHLE/ref=sr_1_6?ie=UTF8&qid=1470511808&sr=8-6&keywords=relay

Female Connector, 0.125IN (similar to this one)
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B011CPJ6TM/ref=biss_dp_t_asn

14 Gauge Stranded Wire

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

20%
Rhinoceros 5

comments.text: Sorry I do not have a video on it. I basically wired the hot from the main power switch out to the outlet, which also goes to the relay. The relay switched hot goes out to the power supply. Neutral does not change, just ran a connection to the Outlet. You can also run a ground line if needed. Getting the power supply out was fun, because mine was just press fitted in there. I had to get some leverage to force it out, but mine is an older model without the bottom cover (things might have changed so remove at your own risk.) I kind of threw the mount together really quickly, but it works good enough for me. I had to drill some holes in the Robo3d and one is noticeable, but the Robo team already had two others there. I used laptop type screws to secure the mount. I really like the way it works. Also, do all of this at your own risk as I did. I do not take any responsibility if anything goes wrong. Good Luck!

description.text:
Update V2: Strengthened some weak spots in the design and removed excessive fillets, simplifying the structure. Print with the hooks facing upwards. Only use supports in the upper triangular windows, otherwise it gets messy to remove them.

Battery compartment for the Quad. Best used in conjunction with these landing feet in order to get the space necessary underneath. I like my multis with a low CG. The comparment is made for 3S 1300 mAh LiPos and should fit most makes out there.

The little thingy between the upper an lower platforms on the rear view photograph is a BT module support that comes in many different configurations.

Enjoy!

comments.author: Remi22

comments.text: Hi, The inner longitudal cross-section of the box are 36 x 25 mm. The length of the battery ideally is less than 72 mm but it is no limit to the length really as the inward facing end of the box is open. The cut outs at the open end are for rubber bands to center, going around the back end of the box. Bear in mind that the four screws /w nuts in front of the box must be made flush with the surface to allow for pushing the battery in place.

This is a remix of CheesePatrol's object, the Qidi Tech 1 - magnetic door stop.

Attaching this object underneath the printer's handle and inserting magnets into the opposite end of the object creates a magnetic latch that holds the Qidi Tech 3D printer's door shut and also stops it from swinging inside the 3D Printer.

The neodymium magnets that I used were smaller in diameter at 6.35mm than the 8mm in the original object, which required a little re-design on my part.

I used OpenSCAD to import CheesePatrol's qidi-door-magnet-outside-mount.stl, fill in his magnet holes and hollow out a smaller hole for my 6.35mm magnets.

author: UBuildABook

description.text:
Just a quick, simple design for an arm to mount my camera setup to my ceiling. Inspired by those desk lamps with spring balanced arms, just tossed this design together to help me create future youTube videos in my office and also be able to push it out of the way when not in use.

Here's a quick youtube video I made of the assembly:
https://youtu.be/R1vH0Aan2yA

I might make changes in the future, but it's functional for my purposes as is and probably won't any time soon.

Let me know what you think!

Very roughly, here is everything you'll need:
Print (I printed everything in PETG, 50% infill)
-- (1) Bottom Plate
-- (1) Camera Cradle (or design one for your camera. Mine is dimensioned for my Sony mirrorless camera)
-- (2) Center Plates
-- (1) Top Mount
-- (1) Ceiling Mount
-- (2) Ram Balls

-- 4" Lazy Susan Bearing
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001EI2SL6/

-- Ram Ball Clamp
https://www.amazon.com/Mount-Composite-Double-Socket-1-Inch/dp/B005KWPJ04/

-- (4) Springs
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00E7PU0QS/

-- Rope or strap to tension springs

-- 1" x 1" x 1/8" aluminum channel, cut to the length you need (could probably use thinner than that, and channel not necessary. My original design was to run the springs inside in the channel, but scrapped that idea later)

And very roughly, the assorted screws (I might be missing a couple?)
-- (4) Wood Screws (to the ceiling)
-- (4) M4 x 10mm socket cap screws
-- (4) M4 x 8mm button head screws
-- (8) M4 square nuts
-- (4) 1/4 x 3" screws
-- (4) 1/4 x 2" screws
-- (16) 1/4 nuts

comments.text: That's a nice design and it appears very functional.  I really like how finished out you made it.  Great contribution to the community!  I see one of these in my future!
comments.author: medic265

comments.text:
Thanks!
I think I'll be upgrading the bearing soon. It hasn't failed, but is sagging a bit. I might try to find a more robust bearing (roller bearing maybe). I'll post the update if I make it!

Great for low security situations.

3x 18650 Battery Sled for Hammond 1590B enclosure.

Bottom of the sled wraps around the screw posts of the 1590B enclosure and has a protective barrier to make sure the terminals can't short against the enclosure. Also has channels on the bottom to route the bottom wires to the top of the sled.

I prefer to "top-mount" the battery clips, I'm worried that when bottom-mounted the downward force when inserting the battery could, over time, cause the clip/terminal to slide down and short against the enclosure.

Uses the Keystone 228 for the positive contacts and the 209 for the negative. Always remove the battery clip/terminals from the sled when soldering your lead wires!

description.text:
I invented this press back in 2008. Applied for a patent and it was issued in September 2009. I have since let the patent expire. I have sold near 1000 presses in the last 8 years and have discontinued making and selling them because of age. The last model is V4 and it sold on eBay for $85, free shipping in the US.

The video shows how I made the Press and how to use it to pad stacks of paper. It can pad up to 1000 sheets of 20 lb paper and up to 11 inches wide.

I can pad a stack of paper in 4 minutes. Not including the adhesive drying time.

This is a 2:1 proportional caliper. If you set the larger end to a distance, flipping it over will yield exactly half that distance between the other two points.

That's it!

I was drawing Voronoi diagrams and I didn't want to mess with a bunch of compass constructions to find the midpoint of so many lines.

You could also use it for taking measurements when drawing from life, but you're stuck with the 2:1 proportion.

If you want to change the proportion you need to change the location of the pivot:

A 1:1 ratio would place the pivot at 1/(1+1) the length of the calipers, or halfway (duh).

A 1:3 ratio would have the pivot at 1/(1+3) the length of the calipers: 1/4 of the length.

As I've said these are at a 2:1 (or 1:2) ratio which is why the pivot is at 1/(1+2) or 1/3 of the length.

description.text:
Track adapter for using TrackMaster tracks with common wood track. Still a work in progress...

I saw one of these on eBay for $12, but could not find a model of it anywhere else. Being cheap, I designed one for everyone.

So far it fits great with the wooden track pieces that I have.

With the v2, I tried to make a better fit and transition from the Trackmaster to Wooden track.

If you print with a layer height of .2mm, the ramp section will have grip steps that almost match the Trackmaster side of the model.

I still have to lengthen the incline section of the model. Sometimes the train will hang up when going from Trackmaster to wooden track. It works fine if going from wooden to Trackmaster.

Printer:

HicTop

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printed with PLA at 210 on a heated bed at 50. Supports were used for better quality of the overhanging parts of the model. They might not be needed.
v2
v2 Connection changes...

description.text:
replacement display stand for Diamond Select's uss Enterprise D and E (may work for others)
requiters a 1/2 inch dowel rod, and sometimes a 1/2 inch drill bit.

the adapter is for the Enterprise D and may need some epoxy glue, it replaces the white plastic bit that the ball pivot is in.

the Enterprise E ball pivot can be pushed out from inside the battery cover and the dowel rod will fit in the hole perfectly.

Printer:

Wanhao i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

any, but i used .3

Infill:

if using PETG, 35+

Notes:

using PETG i had to increase my heat bed temperature to 90c (and re-level it) to stop the print from warping.

extra note:
you should get a sheet of PEI plastic for your heat bed before trying to print this, it will make it a lot easier to remove. (as long as you only hold the sheet on with clips)

author: Jhonspikeder

description.text: This model was inspired by the famous Peggy's Cove lighthouse in Nova Scotia. I split it into four parts due to the limited dimensions on my printer.  Looks great in front of our house!

I printed the three pieces that make up the base in white PLA  and glued them together.  The top cover was in red PLA. I printed two copies of the LED holders inside the top portion for two LEDs using glow-in-the-dark filament. This keeps it glowing for a short period of time after the LEDs turn off.  The wiring to the LEDs travels through the base and out to an external solar panel (taken from a standard solar lighting system),  All layers were 0.1mm in size.  I printed it half-scale due to my printer limitations, I think it could be printed full-scale on a printer capable of a 8" x 8" x 8" model.

comments.text: Looks awesome! - Did you need any support for the top RED part?

title: Case for Metric Tap & Die Set (Irwin/Hanson 12 pc)

description.text:
This is a case for the Irwin/Hanson 12 pc metric tap & die set. Like alaubhan I found the factory packaging just wouldn't work for keeping the tools. I liked his "Tap / Die Tray for 12 Piece Irwin Hansen Metric Set" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:161622 but I wanted something more portable and tossable.

The case has what I am calling a tap side and a die side. Two versions of the tap side are provided, with a hanger and without. (the picture shows it with the hanger)

There are some limitations with this case because of the nature of 3D printing. I would print both sides at 100% infill. It really doesn't take much longer and the snap fits of the taps will be sturdier (depending on your printer some adjustments to the tap fits may be required). The tall die holders can be fragile so be careful. I have found sliding the dies in from the side works pretty well. I rarely use a die anyway. Also be careful about opening the case by lifting on the latch tab on the die side, that works the weak grain of the tab. The case should open if you press in on the tap side just below the tab with your thumb. Some filing of the tab may be required to get the engagement just right. It should close with a satisfying click and open with a moderate press.

For hinge pins I used 4-40 x .5 cap screws. I suppose because it is a case for metric taps I should have use M3's. Those should work as well. I drilled and tapped the hinge knuckles on the tap side for the screws and drilled tight clearance holes on the die side knuckles to pivot on the screws.

You can also see in the photo the "Handles for small taps (sae and metric)"

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1701162

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Infill:

100%

description.text:
I needed a way to attach GoPro to a daybag on my sea kayak. This mount can be clipped to the daybag's closing strap, though it will need something to stabilize it on top. I used a torsion spring from a clothespin in the clip and a paperclip wire for the axis.

You will need to drill slanted holes to pass the arms of your torsion spring through the top and bottom plates - just where depends on the spring you use. You can see couple of extra holes in my plates that I made before I figured it out. Cut the protruding spring wires so they don't snag on things.

I've included a 70mm extender that was necessary to get the camera above the bag.

This uses modules from my OpenSCAD primitives library. I've included the files in this Thing (code assumes they are under plib/...), but they are also available on GitHub (https://github.com/imageguy/openscad_primitives) and as a Thing
(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1679551).

Please feel free to use, share as modify as you see fit.

Printer:

TwoUp

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

Solid

Notes:

I printed this in ABS using 0.2mm layer thickness. The supports are included.

Finishing prongs

After removing the supports between prongs, I use 80 grit sandpaper folded around a thin piece of metal to smooth them.

title: Toppers for PEX (SharkBite) to hold PixaBulb
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
These are designed to go on top of PEX tubing commonly sold under the brand SharkBite. Its available at many hardware stores including Home Depot.

They hold the base only of a PixaBulb (remove clear lens).

Here is an overview:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7jwMc-yHRuU

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm layers

Infill:

Fast Honeycomb, 10%

Notes:

I have included the factory files for Simplify 3D which will correctly position the lenses so the center is lined up with the center of a hexagon for the fill. This is important so the correct fill gets printed. See screenshot for reference.

Assembly

Print one bulb holder for each shell. The bulb holder is press fitted into the base of the shell with the surface that was on your print platform going in first so its completely open at the base. A dab of glue or Acetone (if you printed in ABS) will secure the ring in place. Make sure to test fit a PixaBulb and place on a piece of 1" PEX to insure you have the ring far enough inside.

The correct depth should leave 1/2" from the bottom of the ring to the base of the shell. This will allow the assembly to slide over the top of the PEX 1/2".

After you have mounted your inner ring and secured it (glue/acetone), remove the plastic lens of a PixaBulb node. You won't need it. Insert the base of the pixabulb into the interior ring making sure to line up the wires with the notches of the ring.

Thread the pixabulb wires through your piece of PEX (you will likely have to solder on extensions unless you are making these real short). Place the topper on the end of the PEX and gently press into place. You should not need any further attachment bonding. But, if you feel it necessary, a sheet metal screw can be screwed through the lens and into the PEX but I do not feel this is necessary.

title: Team UnLimbited Gauntlet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This release contains all the required files to create reverse dovetail thermo-formed gauntlets for e-nable devices and is currently compatible with both Raptor Reloaded and Phoenix hands. Printed in PLA the gauntlet is heated when printed to form a natural, strong gauntlet.

This release also includes the Autodesk Fusion 360 source archive to allow for easier modification and customisation of this gauntlet.

This release contains the following files :-

V4 Thermo-form gauntlet, this scales at the same size as the e-nable device being produced.
Forming Jig to allow shaping to be performed without the recipient / without risk of burns to the recipient.

Team UnLimited 3 pin partial adaptive grip;
Customised tension box pin that has an internal rounder surface for the Team UnLimited 3 pin adaptive grip system.
Team UnLimbited Thermo-form Reverse Dovetail Advantages

Significantly stronger than standard printed gauntlet.
Lighter than standard gauntlet.
Much faster printing time.
Allows for a more natural forming shape
Recipient reported advantages include :-
Better fitting, more comfortable
Feels more "connected"
Improved performance with device, able to create better, stronger grip.
Team UnLimbited Thermo-form Reverse Dovetail Features

Reverse dovetail to allow for a more natural forming of the gauntlet without distorting the tensioner block interface.
Dual strap mounts to eliminate the use of wide velcro and the associated comfort problem it creates.
Use either narrow velcro double sided tape or pre-made velcro straps to secure the gauntlet; both available on eBay etc.
Crescent Moon front wrist pressure release area to aid with comfort.
Suggested lining material is Dr Scholl moleskin plus padding roll, if the device is correctly sized and formed then there should be no need for additional foam padding.
As ever the recipient should wear a prosthetic sock with any e-NABLE device.

description.text:
This is a baseplate designed to fit the 16 round cz75 and mec gar magazines. It is not a + extension; just a copy of the extended pad that CZ makes.

Edit: I added a version with less material between the lip on the magazine and the frame. Some of my mags wouldn't go in the frame far enough to reach the mag catch with the original version, but not all of them.

You can check to see which version you need by inserting a magazine without the base pad on it and measuring the distance from the top of the magazine lip to the frame. If it is around 1mm, you will need the thinner version. If it is around 2mm, use the original model.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I would suggest ABS, Nylon, or Polymax filament because good layer adhesion is needed, so make sure you know your printer if you want these to function and be reliable.

I used ABS at first and although I had no issues, I now switched over to Taulman Bridge and they feel much tougher. I think they will last much longer using nylon over ABS.

description.text:
Originally designed by constal (https://tinkercad.com/things/inrsbKb5iE0) and shared under CC BY-NC-SA 3.0.

I modified it by removing the manual supports on the top piece to let the slicer generate it's own supports.

There are holes for the screw terminals. The wires are just coming out of the side in the photo because I needed to tap some additional signals on the board.

Note: The labels on the outside of the box (+12V, GND, K0, K1) may be in reverse order than what they actually are on the thermostat board. Please check the labels on the board itself when making connections.
